title: Containerize the Hive System with Docker
description: To make our Hive system more portable and scalable, we need to containerize it. This will involve creating a Dockerfile that can build an image containing the Queen and all necessary dependencies.
instruction:
Create a Docker container for the Hive system. The implementation should:

1. Create a new Dockerfile in the root of the project
2. The Dockerfile should start from a python:3.11-slim base image
3. Copy the entire Hive application code into the container
4. Install all Python dependencies listed in pyproject.toml (use pip install -e . to install in editable mode)
5. Create a .dockerignore file to exclude unnecessary files (.git, __pycache__, .worktrees, etc.)
6. The container's default command should be to start the Queen orchestrator (i.e., CMD ["python", "queen.py"])
7. Set appropriate working directory (/app)
8. Ensure all Hive subdirectories are created (hive/tasks, hive/results, etc.)
9. The final image should be runnable and start the Queen without errors
10. Include a docker-compose.yml file for easy local development

NOTE: Focus on creating a working container that can run the Queen orchestrator. The workers will run inside the container.
acceptance: Docker image builds successfully with: docker build -t hive-system .
Container runs and starts Queen orchestrator
All Hive components are properly included in the image
